p.s: In the given excerpt from William Shakespeare's comedy The Merchant of Venice 1596/97 Shylock encounters Tubal who has both good and bad news for him, which puts Shylock into a conflict between grief and excitement.

When Shylock spots Tubal on a street in Venice, where this scene takes place, he is filled with excitement but he is also nervous and even still a little hopeful that Tubal, who has been looking for Shylock's daughter Jessica, might have been able to find her.
That he can barely wait to hear the news is conveyed to the audience by the direct address of Tubal (l. 1) and his direct questions about the topic and whether or not Tubal has been successful.
As Tubal tells him that he had not been able to find Jessica, Shylock's mood changes quickly into a quiet form of self-pity which he shows in the exclamation [...] there, there, there, there (l. 3).
He still needs some time to realize that his daughter, who was so very dear to him as the metaphor A diamond [...] (l. 3) implies, is now forever gone.
The repetition of two thousand ducats (ll. 3ff) and the alliteration precious, precious (l. 5) show his anger about his losses but also how important money is to him.
It might be something that makes him feel safe because throughout the course of the play it becomes clera that most Venetians only respect him for being good as a merchant.

Now this source of safety got taken by his own daughter and he has to come to the realization that he lacks control over the life of Jessica as her very own father and even over his own life for when his daughter and his money were away he did not know how to react.
Therefore he feels the loss and grief deeply and can even feel cursed; as if all the bad things in the world only always happen to him (ll. 4+7).
The chiasmechiasmus The thief gone with so much, and so much to find the thief (l. 8) reflects his pity for himself, especially for having lost so much money.
The anaphora no satisfaction, no revenge (ll. 8f) add to the previous stylistic devices but show another character trait of Shylock: his revengeful side.
He is mad and angry at his daughter and even at the whole world.
Moreover, he is unable to wish his daughter the best or forgive her in any kind of way: no satisfaction (l. 9) which implies that there is no way she could turn things around again.
Finally the parallelism no sighs but of my breathing; no tears but of my shedding (ll. 9f) ends Shylock's passage of self-pity and anger.
Shylock opens self-reflected but lacks empathy for other people and since so many bad things have happened to him he acts very self-centred and seems to always putting himself.

This can also be noticed throughout the dialogue for Tubal speaks very little and only gives new information to Shylock and the audience while Shylock finds himself expressing all his meotions and hateful thoughts.
Tubal remarks his egoistic perspective (l. 11) while telling him about Antonio.
Shylock is pleased to hear this name in combination with ill luck (l. 11) and gets filled with excitement immediately which is shown in his interruption of Tubal's speech.
His repetition of what (l. 12) and ill luck (l. 12) show his eagerness for the bad luck of a foe of his.
Shylock appears quite moody as his mood changes so quickly from his sadness to happiness about his brand.

The rhetorical system Is't true, is't true? (l. 14) make Shylock seem a little bit childish which makes sense in a way of him finally getting what he was hoping for and gaining back at least the feelign of more control over his life.
The direct address of Tubal (l. 16) expresses Shylock's thankfulness towards Tubal for being a good friend to him by lifting him up.

The alliteration good news, good news (l. 16) underlines how badly he has been waiting for a good thing to happen but also make Shylock appear in a bad light for he is able to find happiness in the defeat of somebody else.
Shylock continues on by asking more questions for he is so excited that he wants more details.
Though the details that Tubal can provide are that his daughter spent a lot of his money already which he will never get back.
This realization hurts Shylock and he shifts back into his sad mood of grief and loss.
The repetitive exclamation foursome ducats [...]!Foursome ducats! express his anger and disbelief in Jessica's behaviour.
Shylock falls back into his self-pity but Tubal reminds him of the ruined Antonio which puts Shylock into a rather neutral tone.
He does not show his excitement as extremely anymore but his contentment about being able to finally get revenge.

The repetition of I am [...] glad of it [...] I am glad of it (l. 22) remark his revengeful side and also build a bracket for the parallelism I'll plague him, I'll torture him (l. 22) which underlines his assertive way to follow his intentions.

As Tubal mentions his dead wife's ring though, Shylock drifts back again to his angry mood and expresses how hurt he is by the fact his daughter gave this ring away in the hyperbole I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys (l. 25).
Shylock's emotions about this ring portray him as a loving and caring husband and father because if he would not care so much about his daughter he would not be so hurt that she left him.
Shylock appears to be quite emotional but not very good at expressing his feelings towards other people.
Tubal retrieves him from his thoughtfulness once again by reminding him that Antonio is certainly ruined.
But after all the bad news about his daughter Shylock is unable to convey as much excitement about this as before.

Still, he lets go of his thoughts about his daughter and wants to forget about them as soon as possible which is delivered to the audience through his action of planning the case at court two weeks ahead.

The repetition Go, Tubal (l. 27) and Go, go Tubal (l. 29) but also at our synagogue; [...] at our synagogue (ll. 29f) underline his enthusiasm about a thing going right in his life and finally getting the chance to get revenge for all the bad things that have happened to him lately.
To conclude one may say that in this excerpt Shylock appears very self-centred by the way he pities himself.
Furthermore, he seems very moody because he feels emotions strongly and changes between anger about his losses and happiness about Antonio's bad luck.
In addition to that Shylock appears revengeful but the audience also gets to know his loving and caring side through his emotions over a ring.
